chapter.title: Blocks and control structures
chapter.para: Method, attribute, and class bodies contain procedural code that is executed when the method or attribute is invoked, or when the class is instantiated. The code contains expressions and control directives and is organized using blocks and control structures.

The Ceylon language has a recursive block structure—statements and declarations that are syntactically valid in the body of a toplevel declaration are, in general, also syntactically valid in the body of a nested declaration or of a control structure, and vice-versa.

section.title: Block structure
section.para: A body is a block, class body or interface body. Every body is list of semicolon-delimited statements, control structures, and declarations, surrounded by braces. Some bodies end in a control directive. Every program element in the list is said to directly occur in the body. A program element directly occurs earlier than a second program element if both program elements directly occur in a body and the first program element occurs earlier in the list than the second program element.
A program element (indirectly) occurs in a body if:

listitem.para: the program element directly occurs in the body, or
the program element indirectly occurs inside the body of a declaration or control structure that occurs directly in the body.

section.para: We sometimes say that the body contains the program element if the program element (indirectly) occurs in the body.
A program element (indirectly) occurs earlier than a second program element if:

listitem.para: the two program elements both directly occur in the same body, and the second program element occurs after the first program element, or
the second program element indirectly occurs inside the body of a declaration or control structure that directly occurs earlier in the same body as the first program element.

section.para: The set of program elements that (indirectly) occur later than a program element is sometimes called the lexical scope of the program element.
A program element sequentially occurs in a body if:

listitem.para: the program element directly occurs in the body, or
the program element sequentially occurs inside the body of a control structure that occurs directly in the body.

section.para: A program element sequentially occurs earlier than a second program element if:

listitem.para: the two program elements both directly occur in the same body, and the second program element occurs after the first program element, or
the second program element sequentially occurs inside the body of a control structure that directly occurs earlier in the same body as the first program element.

section.para: If a program element sequentially occurs earlier than a second program element, the sequence of statements from the first program element to the second program element comprises:

listitem.para: the sequence of statements that occur directly in the body in which the first program element directly occurs, beginning from the first program element and ending with the second program element, if the second program element occurs directly in the same body as the first program element, or

the sequence of statements that occur directly in the body in which the first program element directly occurs, beginning from the first program element and ending with the declaration or control structure in whose body the second program element sequentially occurs, followed by the sequence of statements from the first statement of the declaration whose body contains the second program element to the second program element itself, otherwise.

section.title: Declaration name uniqueness
section.para: A package may not contain two toplevel declarations (interfaces, classes, methods, or attributes) with the same name.
A program element is contained within the namespace of a declaration if either:

listitem.para: it directly occurs in the body in which the declaration directly occurs,
the declaration is a parameter or type parameter, and it directly occurs in the body of the parameterized declaration,
it is a control structure variable or iteration variable of a control structure contained in the namespace of the declaration, or
it directly occurs in the body of a control structure contained in the namespace of the declaration.

section.para: The namespace of a declaration may not contain a second declaration with the same name. (A parameter or type parameter is considered to be a declaration that is directly contained by the body of the declaration it parameterizes.)
A class or interface may not inherit a declaration with the same name as a declaration it contains unless either:

listitem.para: the contained declaration directly or indirectly refines the inherited declaration,
the contained declaration is an initializer parameter of the class, or
the inherited declaration is a block local declaration.

section.para: A class or interface may not inherit two declarations with the same name unless either:

listitem.para: both of the inherited declarations are formal and directly or indirectly refine some member of a common supertype,

the class or interface contains a declaration that directly or indirectly refines both the inherited declarations (in which case both the inherited declarations directly or indirectly refine some member of a common supertype),
one of the inherited declarations directly or indirectly refines the other inherited declaration, or
at least one of the inherited declarations is a block local declaration.

section.title: Scope of a declaration
section.para: The scope of a declaration is governed by the body or package in which it occurs. A declaration is in scope at a program element if and only if either:

listitem.para: the declaration is a parameter or type parameter of a declaration whose body contains the program element,
the declaration is a control structure variable or iteration variable belonging to a block of a control structure that contains the program element,
the program element belongs to or is contained in the body of the declaration itself,
the program element belongs to or is contained in the body of a class or interface which inherits the declaration,
the declaration directly occurs in a body containing the program element,
the declaration is imported by the compilation unit containing the program element and is visible to the program element, or
the declaration is a toplevel declaration in the package containing the program element.

section.para: Where:

listitem.para: A control structure variable or iteration variable belongs to a block of a control structure if the block immediately follows the declaration of the variable.
A program element belongs to a declaration if it occurs in the extends, satisfies, of, given, abstracts, adapts or is clause of the declaration.

section.title: Hiding a declaration
section.para: If two declarations with the same name are both in scope at a certain program element, then one declaration may hide the other declaration.

listitem.para: If an inner body is contained (directly or indirectly) in an outer body, a declaration that is in scope in the inner body but is not in scope in the outer body hides a declaration that is in scope in the outer body. (In particular, a declaration inherited by a nested class or interface hides a declaration of the containing body.)
An initializer parameter of a class containing the program element hides a declaration inherited by the class.
An actual declaration hides the declaration it refines.
A declaration occurring in a body containing the program element hides a declaration imported by the compilation unit containing the body or implicitly imported from the module ceylon.language.
A toplevel declaration of the package containing the program element hides a declaration implicitly imported from the module ceylon.language.
A declaration explicitly imported by the compilation unit containing the program element hides a declaration implicitly imported from the module ceylon.language.
A declaration explicitly imported by the compilation unit containing the program element hides a toplevel declaration of the package containing the compilation unit.
A declaration explicity imported by name in the compilation unit containing the program element hides a declaration explicitly imported by wildcard in the compilation unit.

section.title: Referenceability of a declaration
section.para: A declaration may be in scope at a program element, but not referenceable at the program element. A declaration is referenceable at a program element if the declaration is in scope at the program element and either:

listitem.para: the program element occurs within the lexical scope of the declaration, or
the declaration does not directly occur in a block or in the initializer section of a class body.

section.para: Note that these rules have very different consequences for:

listitem.para: declarations that occur in blocks and class initializer sections, and
toplevel declarations, and declarations that occur in class declaration sections and interface bodies.

section.para: Declarations that occurs in a block or class initializer section are interspersed with procedural code that initializes simple attributes or locals. Therefore, a program element in a block or initializer may not refer to a declaration that occurs later in the block or class body. This restriction does not apply to declarations that occur in an interface body or class declaration section.

section.title: Type determinability of a declaration
section.para: An attribute declared using the keyword value or a method declared using the keyword function may be in scope at a program element, but its type may not be determinable at the program element.

The type of an attribute or method declared using the keyword value or function is determinable at a program element if the declaration is in scope at the program element and the program element occurs within the lexical scope of the declaration.

section.title: Unqualified reference resolution
section.para: An unqualified reference is:

listitem.para: the type name in an unqualified type declaration, for example String or Sequence in Sequence<String>,
the member in name an unqualified value reference, for example counter in counter.count, or
the member name or type name in an unqualified callable reference, for example entries in entries(people[].name).

section.para: If a program element contains an unqualified reference:

listitem.para: There must be at least one declaration with the given name in scope at the program element.

If multiple declarations with the given name are in scope at the program element where the given name occurs, then there must be exactly one such declaration which is not hidden by another declaration.

section.para: Then the given name refers to this unique unhidden declaration, and:

listitem.para: the declaration must be referenceable at the program element,
the type of the declaration must be determinable at the program element, and
if the declaration is forward-declared, it must be definitely initialized at the program element.

section.title: Qualified reference resolution
section.para: A qualified reference is:

listitem.para: the type name in a qualified type declaration, for example Buffer in BufferedReader.Buffer,
the member name in a qualified value reference, for example count in counter.count, or
the member name or type name in a qualified callable reference, for example name in entries(people[].name).

section.para: Every qualified reference has a qualifying type:

listitem.para: For a type declaration, the qualifying type is the full qualified type the qualifies the type name.
For a value reference or callable reference, the qualifying type is the type of the receiver expression.

section.para: If a program element contains a qualified reference:

listitem.para: The qualifying type must have at least one member with the given name which is visible at the program element.
If there are multiple visible members with the given name, then it is guaranteed by the type system that there is exactly one such member which is not refined by another member.

section.para: Then the given name refers to this unique member. If the program element is contained in the body of a class or interface, and the member declaration directly occurs in the body of the class or interface, and the qualified reference is a value reference or callable reference, and the receiver expression is a self reference to the instance being initialized, then:

listitem.para: the member declaration must be referenceable at the program element,
the type of the member must be determinable at the program element, and
if the member declaration is forward-declared, it must be definitely initialized at the program element.

section.title: Closure
section.para: The principle of closure states a that nested body always has access to a set of values for all simple attributes and locals declared by containing bodies.

If a declaration is nested directly or indirectly inside a class or interface declaration, then there is always a current instance of the class or interface when the nested declaration body is executed. The current instance is determined as follows:

listitem.para: for the innermost class or interface declaration that contains the nested declaration, the current instance is the receiving instance of the invocation, evaluation, or assignment, and

for any other class or interface that contains the nested declaration, the current instance is the same object that was the current instance when the initializer of the current instance of the innermost class or interface declaration was executed.

If a declaration is nested directly or indirectly inside a block, then there is always a current frame of the block when the nested declaration is executed. The current frame contains the values of all non-variable locals declared by the block. The current frame is determined as follows:

listitem.para: if the nested declaration is nested directly inside a block, the current frame contains the current values at the point of execution of the value reference expression or callable reference expression that refers to the nested declaration, or, otherwise

if the nested declaration is contained inside the body of another nested declaration, the current frame is the current frame of the containing declaration at the point of execution of the value reference expression or callable reference expression that refers to the nested declaration.

section.title: References within a closure
section.para: The initializer of a class, or the body of a member of a class may instantiate, invoke, evaluate or assign members of the current instance of the class which defines the initializer or member—the instance being instantiated or invoked—without explicitly specifying the receiver, or by specifying a self reference this as the receiver.

The initializer of a nested class, or the body of a member of a nested class or nested interface may invoke, evaluate or assign members of the current instance of the containing class or interface—the parent instance of the instance being instantiated or invoked—without explicitly specifying the receiver, or by specifying an outer instance reference outer as the receiver.
A toplevel method or attribute body may not refer to a self reference, since there is no current instance.

The body of a method, class, or attribute nested inside the body of another method or attribute may invoke or evaluate any local, block local attribute getter or block local method whose declaration indirectly occurs earlier within the containing scope.

section.title: Blocks and statements
section.para: A block is list of semicolon-delimited statements, control structures, and declarations, surrounded by braces.
A statement is an assignment or specification, an invocation of a method, an instantiation of a class, a control structure, or a control directive.

The statements, local specifiers, and control structures that directly occur in a block are executed sequentially in the order that they appear inside the block. Execution of a block begins at the first statement, local specifier, or control structure of the block. Execution of a block terminates when the last statement, local specifier, or control structure of the block finishes executing, when a control directive that terminates the block is executed, or when an exception is thrown.
A statement or declaration contained in a block may not evaluate an attribute or local, invoke a method, instantiate a class, or extend a class whose declaration occurs later in the block.
Every block local declaration must be used somewhere inside the block in which it is declared.

section.title: Control directives
section.para: Control directive statements end execution of the current block and force the flow of execution to resume in some outer scope. They may only appear at the end of a block.
Ceylon provides the following control directives:

itemizedlist.listitem: the return directive—to return a value from a non-void method or attribute getter or terminate execution of a void method, setter, or class initializer,
the break directive—to terminate a loop,
the continue directive—to jump to the next iteration of a loop, and
the throw directive—to raise an exception.

section.para: For example:

The return directive must sequentially occur in the body of a method, attribute getter, attribute setter, or class initializer. In the case of a void method, attribute setter, or class initializer, no expression may be specified. In the case of a non-void method or attribute getter, an expression must be specified. The expression type must be assignable to the return type of the method or the type of the attribute. When the directive is executed, the expression is evaluated to determine the return value of the method or attribute getter.
The break directive must sequentially occur in the body of a loop.
The continue directive must sequentially occur in the body of a loop.

A throw directive may appear anywhere and may specify an expression of type ceylon.language.Exception. When the directive is executed, the expression is evaluated and the resulting exception is thrown. If no expression is specified, the directive is equivalent to throw Exception().

section.title: Specification statements
section.para: A specification statement may specify the value of a forward-declared, non-variable simple attribute or local or the method reference of a forward-declared method.

Note that the Ceylon language distinguishes between assignment to a variable value (the := operator) and specification of the value of a non-variable local or attribute (using =). The = character is not an operator, and therefore a specification statement is not an expression statement.

A specification statement consists of an unqualified value reference and a specifier. The value reference must refer to a declaration which sequentially occurs earlier in the body in which the specification statement occurs.
The type of the specified expression must be assignable to the type of the simple attribute or local, or to the callable type of the method.

section.title: Definite return
section.para: A sequence of statements may definitely return.

listitem.para: A sequence of statements definitely returns if it ends in a return or throw directive, or in a control structure that definitely returns.
A body definitely returns if it contains a list of statements that definitely returns.
An if conditional definitely returns if it has an else block and both the if and else blocks definitely return.
A switch conditional definitely returns if all case blocks definitely return and the else block, if any, definitely returns.
A for loop definitely returns if it has an else block that definitely returns, and there is no break directive in the for block.
A while loop does not definitely return.
A do/while loop definitely returns if the do block definitely returns.
A try/catch exception manager definitely returns if the try block definitely returns and all catch blocks definitely return or if the finally block definitely returns.

section.para: The body of a non-void method or getter must definitely return.

A body may not contain an additional statement, control structure, or declaration following a sequence of statements that definitely returns. Such a statement, control structure, or declaration is considered unreachable.

section.title: Definite initialization
section.para: A sequence of statements may definitely initialize a forward-declared local, simple attribute, or method.

listitem.para: A sequence of statements definitely initializes a local, simple attribute, or method if one of the statements is a specification statement or assigment expression for the local or simple attribute or a control structure that definitely initializes the local or simple attribute, or if the sequence of statements ends in a return or throw directive.
An if conditional definitely initializes a local, simple attribute, or method if it has an else block and both the if and else blocks definitely initialize the local or simple attribute.

A switch conditional definitely initializes a local, simple attribute, or method if all case blocks definitely initialize the local, simple attribute, or method and the else block, if any, definitely initializes the local, simple attribute, or method.

A for loop definitely initializes a local, simple attribute, or method if it has an else block that definitely initializes the local, simple attribute, or method, and there is no break directive in the for block.
A while loop does not definitely initialize a local, simple attribute, or method.

A try/catch exception manager definitely initializes a local, simple attribute, or method if the try block definitely initializes the local, simple attribute, or method and all catch blocks definitely initialize the local, simple attribute, or method or if the finally block definitely initializes the local, simple attribute, or method.

section.para: A local, simple attribute, or method is considered definitely initialized at a certain statement or declaration if its declaration has a specifier or initializer, if it is referenced by a parameter, or if it is definitely initialized by the sequence of statements from its declaration to the given statement or declaration.
A local, simple attribute, or method must be definitely initialized wherever any value reference to it occurs as an expression within the body in which it is declared.
A shared forward-declared simple attribute or method must be definitely initialized:

listitem.para: at every return statement of the initializer of the containing class, and
at the very last expression statement, directive statement or specification statement of the initializer of the containing class.

section.para: A specification statement for a method or non-variable simple attribute or local may not (indirectly) occur in a for or while block unless the declaration itself occurs within the same for or while block.

section.title: Definite uninitialization
section.para: A sequence of statements may possibly initialize a forward-declared local, simple attribute, or method.

listitem.para: A sequence of statements possibly initializes a local, simple attribute, or method if one of the statements is a specification statement for the local, simple attribute, or method or a control structure that possibly initializes the local, simple attribute, or method.

An if conditional possibly initializes a local, simple attribute, or method if either the if block possibly initializes the local, simple attribute, or method or if the else block, if any, possibly initializes the local, simple attribute, or method.

A switch conditional possibly initializes a local, simple attribute, or method if one of the case blocks possibly initializes the local, simple attribute, or method or the else block, if any, possibly initializes the local, simple attribute, or method.

A for loop possibly initializes a local, simple attribute, or method if the for block possibly initializes the local, simple attribute, or method or if it has an else block that possibly initializes the local, simple attribute, or method.
A while loop possibly initializes a local, simple attribute, or method if the while block possibly initializes the local, simple attribute, or method.

A try/catch exception manager possibly initializes a local, simple attribute, or method if the try block possibly initializes the local, simple attribute, or method, if one of the catch blocks possibly initializes the local, simple attribute, or method, or if the finally block possibly initializes the local, simple attribute, or method.

section.para: A forward-declared local, simple attribute, or method is considered definitely uninitialized at a certain statement or declaration if:

listitem.para: it is not possibly initialized by the sequence of statements from its declaration to the given statement or declaration,
the statement does not (indirectly) occur in the for block or else block of a for loop with a for block that possibly initializes it,
the statement does not (indirectly) occur in the while block of a while loop with a while block that possibly initializes it,
the statement does not (indirectly) occur in a catch block of a try/catch exception manager with a try block that possibly initializes it, and
the statement does not (indirectly) occur in the finally block of a try/catch exception manager with a try block or catch block that possibly initializes it.

section.para: A method or non-variable local or simple attribute must be definitely uninitialized wherever any value reference to it occurs as a specification statement within the body in which it is declared.

section.title: Control structures
section.para: Control of execution flow may be achieved using control directives and control structures. Control structures include conditionals, loops, and exception management.
Ceylon provides the following control structures:

listitem.para: the if/else conditional—for controlling execution based upon a boolean condition, type condition, or check for a non-null or non-empty value,
the switch/case/else conditional—for controlling execution using an enumerated list of values or types,
the while loop—for loops which terminate based a boolean condition,
the for/else loop—for looping over elements of a collection, and
the try/catch/finally exception manager—for managing exceptions and controlling the lifecycle of objects which require explicit destruction.

section.programlisting: ControlStructure: IfElse | SwitchCaseElse | While | ForFail | TryCatchFinally
section.para: Control structures are not considered to be expressions, and therefore do not evaluate to a value.

section.title: Control structure variables
section.para: Some control structures allow inline declaration of a variable, a local that is scoped to the control structure body.

In most cases, the explicit type be omitted, forcing the compiler to infer it, by specifying the keyword value where the type usually appears. The type of the variable is inferred to be the type of the expression that follows.
If the type is missing from the declarations, the type of the variables is inferred.

section.title: Iteration variables
section.para: A for loop requires an iteration variable declaration. An iteration variable declaration must specify an iteration variable.
An iteration variable may be callable.
If the return type is missing from the declaration, the return type of the callable variable is inferred.
An iteration variable of type Entry may be specified in destructured form.

section.title: Control structure conditions
section.para: Some control structures expect conditions. There are five kinds of condition:

listitem.para: a boolean condition is satisfied when a boolean expression evaluates to true,
an assignabilty condition is satisfied when an expression evaluates to an instance of a specified type,
an existence condition is satisfied when an expression evaluates to a non-null value,
a nonemptiness condition is satisfied when an expression evaluates to a non-null, non-empty value, and
a subtype condition is satisfies when a given type is a subtype of the specified type.

section.title: Boolean conditions
section.para: A boolean condition is just an expression.
The expression must be of type Boolean.
The condition is satisfied if the expression evaluates to true when the containing control structure is executed.

section.title: Assignability, existence, and nonemptiness conditions
section.para: An assignability, existence, or nonemptiness condition may contain either:

listitem.para: an unqualified value reference to a non-variable, non-default simple attribute, local, or parameter, or
an inline variable declaration together with an expression.

section.para: In the case of an assignability or existence condition, the type of the variable may be inferred.
The type of the value reference or expression must be:

listitem.para: a type which is not a subtype of the specified type, but whose intersection with the specified type is not exactly Bottom, in the case of an assignability condition,
a type whose intersection with Nothing is not exactly Bottom and whose intersection with Object is not exactly Bottom, in the case of an exists condition, or

a subtype of Nothing|FixedSized<Void> whose intersection with None<Bottom> is not exactly Bottom, and whose intersection with Some<Bottom> is not exactly Bottom, in the case of a nonemptiness condition.

section.para: An assignability condition may narrow to an intersection or union type.
Note that an existence or nonemptiness condition is equivalent to—and may be considered an abbreviation of—an assignability condition:

listitem.para: if (exists x) is equivalent to if (is Object x), and

listitem.para: if the condition contains a value reference, the value will be treated by the compiler as having type T&X where the conditional expression is of type T and X is the specified type, inside the block that immediately follows the condition.

The condition is satisfied if the value reference or expression evaluates to an instance of the required type when the control structure containing the condition is executed:

listitem.para: for an assignability condition, the condition is satisfied if the expression evaluates to an instance of the specified type when the control structure is executed,
for an existence condition, the condition is satisfied unless the expression evaluates to an instance of Nothing when the control structure is executed, or
for a nonemptiness expression, the condition is satisfied unless the expression evaluates to an instance of None or Nothing when the control structure is executed.

section.para: Note that these are formal definitions. In fact, the compiler erases Nothing|T to T before generating bytecode. So if (exists x) is actually processed as if (x!=null) by the virtual machine.

section.title: Subtype conditions
section.para: A subtype condition specifies a specified type (first) and a given type (second).
The given type will be treated by the compiler as a subtype of the specified type inside the block that immediately follows the condition.
The condition is satisfied if the given type is a subtype of the specified type when the control structure containing the condition is executed.

section.title: Exhaustive lists of cases
section.para: A switch statement may be exhaustive. To determine if a switch is exhaustive, we consider the exhaustive list of cases of the switch expression type.
The exhaustive list of cases of an enumerated type T comprises the following types:

listitem.para: every case of T which is an anonymous class, and
every case of T which is not itself an enumerated type, together with
the exhaustive list of cases of every case of T which is itself an enumerated type.

section.para: The exhaustive list of cases of a union type T|U|V|... comprises the following types:

listitem.para: every type belonging to the union which is not an enumerated type, together with
the exhaustive list of cases of every type belonging to the union which is an enumerated type.

section.para: A switch is exhaustive if the union type formed by the types belonging to the exhaustive list of cases of the switch expression type is a subtype of the union type formed from by the types of the cases of the switch.

The for/else loop has the following form:
The for iterator consists of an iteration variable declaration and an iterated expression that contains the range of values to be iterated.
The type of the iterated expression depends upon the iteration variable declarations:

listitem.para: The iterated expression must be an expression of type assignable to Iterable<X> where X is the declared type of the iteration variable.
If two iteration variables are defined, the iterated expression type must be assignable to Iterable<Entry<U,V>> where U and V are the declared types of the iteration variables.

section.para: When the construct is executed:

listitem.para: the iterator is obtained by evaluating iterator, and then
the for block is executed once for each value of type X produced by the iterator, until the iterator is exhausted, or until a break, return, or throw directive is executed.

section.para: Note that:

listitem.para: if the iterated expression is a range constructor expression, the compiler is permitted to optimize away creation of the Range, and generate the indices using the successor operation.

section.para: We say that the loop exits early if it ends via execution of a break, return, or throw directive. Otherwise, we say that the loop completes normally.
If the loop completes normally, the else block is executed. Otherwise, if the loop exists early, the else block is not executed.

The while loop has the form:
The loop condition determines when the loop terminates.

When the construct is executed, the loop condition is evaluated repeatedly until the first time the condition is not satisfied, or until a break, return, or throw directive is executed. Each time the condition is satisfied, the block is executed.

The try/catch/finally exception manager has the form:

Each catch block defines a variable. The type of the variable must be assignable to ceylon.language.Exception. If no type is explicitly specified, the type is inferred to be ceylon.language.Exception.
A catch block type may be a union or intersection type:
If there are multiple catch blocks in a certain control structure, then:

listitem.para: The type of a catch variable may not be a subtype of any catch variable of an earlier catch block belonging to the same control structure.
If the type of a catch variable is a union type E1|E2|...|En then no member Ei of the union may be a subtype of any catch variable of an earlier catch block belonging to the same control structure.

section.para: The try block may declare a resource expression, which may be either:

listitem.para: an unqualified value reference to a non-variable attribute or local,
an instantiation expression, or
an inline variable declaration together with an expression.

section.para: A resource expresson produces a heavyweight object that must be released when execution of the try terminates. Each resource expression must be of type assignable to ceylon.language.Closeable.
section.programlisting: Resource: MemberName | InitializerReference Arguments | Variable Specifier
section.para: When the construct is executed:

listitem.para: the resource expression, if any, is evaluated, and then open() is called on the resulting resource instance, then
the try block is executed, then
close() is called on the resource instance, if any, with the exception that propagated out of the try block, if any, then
if an exception did propagate out of the try block, the first catch block with a variable to which the exception is assignable, if any, is executed, and then
the finally block, if any, is executed.
